dc:description: Colony-stimulating factor 2 receptor alpha (CSF2RA) was first reported in relation to pseudoautosomal recessive pulmonary alveolar proteinosis simultaneously by two research groups in 2008 (Martinez-Moczygemba et al., PMID: 18955567; Suzuki et. al., PMID: 18955570). *CSF2RA* is located in the pseudoautosomal region (PAR1) of the X and Y chromosomes and is associated with either biallelic or hemizygous (Turner syndrome) variation. *CSF2RA* is part of the receptor complex for the granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) which is involved in the signaling pathway responsible for alveolar macrophage development and function (PMID: 26324812). Alveolar macrophages are responsible for immune response, clearing debris, and surfactant turnover in the lungs. The accumulation of debris and lack of surfactant turnover leads to pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP). PAP can develop as a result of autoantibodies to GM-CSF (>90% of cases) or to germline variation in the GM-CSF receptor complex. Characteristic features of disease can include but are not limited to: milky bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, crazy-paving pattern on radiograph, enlarged and foamy appearing macrophages, dyspnea, respiratory insufficiency, or cyanosis (PMID: 30846703). Age of onset for hereditary forms of PAP is apparently highly variable with a majority of cases in this curation presenting in late infancy or childhood. Six variants (missense, nonsense, canonical splice site, and frameshift deletion) that have been reported in six probands in 2 publications (PMIDs 20622029, 25425184) are included in this curation. The mechanism of pathogenicity appears to be loss of function. This gene-disease relationship is also supported by a mouse model that nearly fully recapitulates the human patient phenotype, expression studies, and rescue of function in patient iPSC cells transfected with wildtype *CSF2RA* (PMIDs: 20622029, 26484569, 35043685, 24279725). In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting the relationship between *CSF2RA* and pseudoautosomal recessive pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Interstitial Lung Disease GCEP on the meeting date September 16, 2025 (SOP Version 11).

evidence.dc:description: Score is reduced 0.5pts for consanguinity in the family and an additional 0.5pts for homozygosity

evidence.rdfs:label: Trapnell_PatientB
evidence.detectionMethod: Direct sequencing of CSF2RA coding exons either from genomic DNA or cDNA, it is not specified which was used for this proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Medical history of pneumonia and sepsis at 2.5yo and at publication required continuous supplemental oxygen - negative GM-CSF autoantibodies
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Screened for variants in SFTPB, SFTPC, and ABCA3

evidence.dc:description: Absent from gnomAD v4.1 - Skipping of the out-of-frame penultimate exon is predicted to lead to a premature stop codon in the terminal exon and expected to escape nonsense mediated decay - Reduce score by 0.5pts for consanguineous parentage - Reduce score by 0.5pts for homozygosity

evidence.rdfs:label: Hildebrandt_PtB
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Hypoxic in room air and height/weight <5th percentile at presentation - negative for GM-CSF autoantibodies
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Direct sequencing of SFTPB, SFTPC and, ABCA3

evidence.dc:description: Absent from gnomAD v4.1 - reduce score by 0.5pts for consanguineous parentage - reduce score by 0.5pts for homozygosity

evidence.rdfs:label: Hildebrandt_PtH
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis diagnosis by histology, treatment with glucocorticosteroids but servere infectious complications occured during use - negative for GM-CSF autoantibodies
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Direct sequencing of SFTPB, SFTPC and, ABCA3

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: increased serum GM-CSF - negative for GM-CSF autoantibodies
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Direct sequencing of SFTPB, SFTPC and, ABCA3

evidence.dc:description: The variant leads to both frame shift and in-frame deletions as alternative splice forms and absent quantitative evidence that the frame shift transcript is the most common, the variant is not scored as a predicted null

evidence.rdfs:label: Trapnell_PatientE
evidence.detectionMethod: Direct sequencing of CSF2RA either genomic or cDNA, authors to not specify which was used for this proband

evidence.dc:description: While not a variant found in human patients, the multi-exon deletion is similar to that found in affecteds. Additionally, the model recapitulated the most common features of the lung disease that is described in humans with homozygous variation in the same gene.

Mice developed the turbid, milky appearance of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid which is an identical finding in affected human patients. Additionally, biomarkers such as GM-CSF were significant increased in the homozygous knockout mice which is also an identical finding to human affecteds.
evidence.rdfs:label: Homozygous CSF2RA knockout in mice

evidence.dc:description: Control cells were able to clear GM-CSF from the growth media while patient derived and differentiated macrophages were not able. Transfection of wildtype CSF2RA in to patient iPSC rescued the GM-CSF clearing phenotype to that of WT levels.
evidence.rdfs:label: Rescue of function in patient derived macrophages

evidence.dc:description: Patient phenotypes are recapitulated by CSF2RA knockout murine models. Further, supplementation of wild type macrophages in CSF2RA knockout mice has been shown to reduce pulmonary disease features associated with pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PMID 38596536).

The milky appearance of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid is indicative of an accumulation of cellular debris, surfactant and other sources of contamination that in healthy individuals is cleared by alveolar macrophages (PMID 26324812). CSF2RA is the alpha subunit of the GM-CSF receptor complex which is an important component in macrophage development and function. CSF2RA expression was not found using flow-cytometry and western blotting in patient samples where it could be detected in healthy relatives. Additionally, in the absence of GM-CSF autoantibodies, there was a marked increase in the levels of GM-CSF both in patient serum and BAL fluid where in a healthy individual none would be detected. Patient lung histology and lung imaging was consistent in the patients with other patients with diagnosed pulmonary alveolar proteinosis.
evidence.rdfs:label: CSF2RA based disruption to alveolar macrophage activity

evidence.dc:description: Increased score to recognize the high level of expression relative to nearly all other screened tissues

Expression data from the GTEx portal were obtained on 07/11/2025 - data shows that the highest expression is in blood with expression in lungs the second highest relative to the other tissues screened
evidence.rdfs:label: GTEx database indicated expression
